instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
When battery is disconnected got 5V and 0.25A on charger on both ports.
With battery connected it turns on but on login screen trackpad/keyboard is not working.
Fan on high RPM and 5V and 0.0A on charger on one port.
Second USB C port got not reaction on USB C volt meter - it is linked with U3100.

Diode mode value and voltages around U3100 looks correct.

I think I will replace but how it can be related with no keyboard/trackpad?

Any idea?

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
You should fix USB-C problem first.

Non working TP/KB may have other reason.

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
Replaced that CD3217 and still got the same issue.

USBC meter shows all diode mode values are correct.

Any idea?

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
Be sure J6700 gets all required voltages.
Try known good trackpad board/flex.

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
"Replaced that CD3217 and still got the same issue."
When battery is disconnected got 5V and 0.25A on charger on both ports.
With battery connected 5V and 0A on one port and no reaction on USB C volt meter on another port.

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message: You can't reach the login screen anymore?

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message: I can but only when battery connected and when will do "jump start" when connect charger.

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
You should fix the USB-C power problem.

Try to enter DFU using SE032 pads.

Did you test the board alone on the desk?

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
"Try to enter DFU using SE032 pads."
no luck

"Did you test the board alone on the desk?"
yes, got 5V and 0.26A on charger and every a few seconds meter turns off and turn on (cycles).
U3900 and U6903 gets warm.

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
Did you try to enter DFU using SE032 pads with both charger and battery connected?
You need to solder wire on the pads and cut off the wire when/if the machine appears in AC2.

Check if required SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages come on from U7800.

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
Soldered wire with SE032/3 and 4.
No DFU mode with battery and charger. The same without battery and charger.

PP1V8_SLPS2R 1.8V
PP1V1_SLPS2R 1.1V
PP0V8_SLPS2R 0.79V

PP1V8_AWAKE 1.79V
PP3V3_AWAKE 3.23V
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE 0.79V
PP1V2_AWAKE 1.19V
PPVDDCPU_AWAKE 0.75V

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message: Keep TP/KB disconnected, when trying DFU with SE032 pads.

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
No DFU mode with battery and charger. The same without battery and charger.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 100458, member: 682"]
Keep TP/KB disconnected, when trying DFU with SE032 pads.
[/QUOTE]

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
Are you using correctly DFU jumper?
heck the example here:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/DFU_Mode_Restore_(Macs)#/media/File:SOC_FORCE_DFU_Jumper.jpg[/URL]

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message: Please correct me if doing something wrong.

threads.title: 820-01598 no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
Connection is correct.
But you should use larger and tinest wire; this helps you tu cut it off.
